comment._content: An aside ! The Bass triangle logo was the first 'trademark' registered in the UK. www.ipo.gov.uk/tmcase/Results/1/UK00000000001

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] I think that's correct. There's no signs of trees having been cut down and they're there in [http://www.flickr.com/photos/91549360@N03]'s streetview.

comment.author: 91549360@N03
comment._content: I'd suggest date closer to 1907. There are no Verlings on Haddington Road in 1901 and Thomas Verling who's occupation is 'hairdresser' is only 26 in 1911. W Verling, his father William, is listed as Able Seaman.( though possibly a barber....there is a pole!!.) Thomas the hairdresser was only 16 in 1902. www.census.nationalarchives.ie/pages/1911/Dublin/Pembroke... I'd imagine the trees would have to have been somewhat established to warrent survey?

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/91549360@N03] Circa 1907 then, under advisement. Interesting that you could be an Able Seaman without being able to read or write.
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: In 1901, William Walsh called himself a Forage Contractor (per the shop sign), but by 1911 he was a Newsagent and Tobacconist, more in line with what he is selling here.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: And the elactric lemp post style seems to point nearer to 1907.  I have nothing to prove it, but somebody might know.

comment.author: 91549360@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Your "elactric lemp post" on the left, known as the Pembroke Standard, dates from1895. i532.photobucket.com/albums/ee327/Falconer1st/Lamposts/La...

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: According to the Irish Independent, James Magan, Hardware Merchant, died on 27th September 1907. There's a Statutory Notice to Creditors in that newspaper on Wednesday, 11 December 1907. However, did the Magans perhaps stay put and stay in business without changing the J. for James over the door? The Freeman's Journal of Monday, 13 January 1913 notes the marriage of James' youngest son, William to a Mary Treacy, originally from Goldsmith Street at Haddington Road Church. Very unusual not to get married in the bride's church, so strong connection with Haddier still indicated?
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/91549360@N03] Dret!  Thenk you.

comment.author: 66151649@N02
comment._content: Vega-tables maybe?

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: Given J. & M. Scanlan over the door of no. 15... James Scanlan of 15 Haddington Road is mentioned as an "Assenting Voter" in the Pembroke District for elections to the St. Stephen's Green Division (Freeman's Journal, 18 March 1904) James was assenting again in a similar election at the start of 1906 (Freeman's Journal, 15 January 1906) By July of 1912, Gerald Scanlan, licensed vintner of Haddington Road was "summoned for having permitted the sale of intoxicating liquor on his licensed premise during prohibited hours" [case was dismissed] (Irish Independent, 31 July 1912) Not great for dating, but really good to see is that both Thomas Verling and Gerald Scanlan contributed to the Church St. Calamity Fund in September 1913 (Freeman's Journal, 11 September 1913)
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Gerald Scanlan 1911, James and Maurice Scanlan (plus WIlliam) in 1901. Not father and son, by the looks of it.

comment.author: 91549360@N03
comment._content: Re; Gable sign. Kenny & Gilse..? . It might be just a coincidence but a Laurence Kenny and a George Gilsenan are listed next to one another in the 1901 census. Both are provision merchants. Gilsenans 'Relation to Head' is "partner"!!!!!. Looking at all the other occupations in their house one would wonder what they all talked about at dinner time? vegatables or vegetables? They might have been renting the shop before Verlings ....as the Verlings were living elsewhere in 1901. No sign of George in 1911 but Larry had been busy. www.census.nationalarchives.ie/pages/1911/Dublin/Arran_Qu...

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/48236157@N02] No. The main road runs across it and is Baggot Street. See maps.osi.ie/publicviewer/#V1,716869,732967,7,9.

comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] I have found a 1940s one inch to the mile map of the whole of Ireland on the National Library of Scotland. It gives a readout of Lat/Long. You can slide the pointer to show a background of Google or Bing aerial photos.
